text: Replication of human immunodeficiency virus-1 in primary human T cells is dependent on the autocrine secretion of tumor necrosis factor through the control of nuclear factor-kappa B activation .

<extra_id_0> Tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> controls T-cell activation and is a major inducer of human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) -1 replication in chronically infected cells .

Therefore , we have investigated its role in primary cultures of HIV-infected human T lymphocytes by using neutralizing anti - <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibodies or <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Primary resting T lymphocytes produced <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and supported HIV replication after T-cell receptor activation .

Addition of neutralizing anti - <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibodies drastically reduced <extra_id_0> p24 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antigen release and prevented <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + cell depletion associated with infection .

text: Anti - <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> also prevented nuclear factor-kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) activation , and a good correlation between this inhibition and inhibition of HIV replication was observed .

Moreover , supplementing the cultures with high doses of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> reverted anti - <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibition of cell proliferation but did not affect the inhibition of HIV <extra_id_0> p24 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antigen release or NF-kappa B activation in the same cultures .

text: Moreover , anti - <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibited HIV-1 long terminal repeat ( LTR ) - driven transcription of a reporter gene in primary T cells in response to activation , either in the presence or the absence of HIV-1 <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Our results support an important role for autocrine <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> secretion in controlling HIV replication in primary T cells because of its ability to maintain NF-kappa B elevated in the nucleus of T cells .
